climbs.name: Western Side in Split - Right Side

content.description:
Located on the left (west) side of the split about two-thirds of the way back, start beneath the left-facing flake, climb the flake and then onto the slopers and finger pocket above.

While the moves on the route are pretty cool, the other wall of the chimney tends to get in the way, and makes falling a real pain on top rope because you're pretty likely to whack the other wall pretty hard.
content.protection: Numerous cracks atop the rock provide sufficient nut placement for a sturdy top rope.  Bring long slings to get the rope over the edge of the split too.

content.description: Traverse left-to-right. The crux is a sequence of four or five moves approaching the split after you come around the corner.
Shimmy up the slot stemming between two faces
content.protection: Top rope
content.location: Far left, of the north face past the dihedral

content.description:
Climb the obvious dihedral and build an anchor in a thin horizontal crack.

For a fun variation can be climbed with your back facing the wall.
content.protection: A few small cams.
content.location: On the far left end of the north face.

content.description: Climb up the huge split in the rock as a chimney, using both sides. Many variants are possible depending on how deep into the split you go and which direction you face, with grades probably varying from 5.2-5.6. All should be done on top-rope.
content.protection: Top-rope, can be anchored on the left or right side of the split. Relatively safe as a solo.
content.location: In the huge split in the rock. Easiest start is deep into the split, just before the large chockstone.

content.description: Same as the 5.8 version, but climb over the bulge fifteen feet up instead of around to the left of it.
content.protection: Set up a toprope using small nuts and friends in the cracks above, or use long slings to equalize between the trees to the left side and the large rock on the right side of the top of the rock.

content.description:
This is the furthest back route on the East (right) side of the crack. This climb involves an interesting sidepull section that pulls you up to a large flat section, and then left of the bulge using sidepulls.

Experienced climbers will be able to climb this without pro, as there are no spectacularly balancy moves, and if you're going to fall, you can lean back into a chimney move on the opposite wall.
content.protection: Set up a toprope using small nuts and friends in the cracks above, or use long slings to equalize between the trees to the left side and the large rock on the right side of the top of the rock.

content.description: A few trickier moves as the arete starts to slant and gets smoother.
content.protection: Top-rope on anchor. Either sling through the drilled holes, or build a gear anchor
content.location: Far left-arete viewing the Split Rock from the south/west (towards the split).

content.description: There are many variations possible. Gets slightly thinner before the top.
content.protection: Top rope on gear anchor
content.location: Climb the South Face, about 5-10 feet right of the split in the rock.

content.description: Fun left-leaning crack climb. Good hands throughout.
content.protection: Top-rope on anchor. Either sling through the drilled holes, or build a gear anchor
content.location: Left-slanting crack in the middle of the left side of the south face, starts about 5 feet left of the split.

content.description:
Short route with a crimp crux at the top.

Move up the starting bulge. Then traverse out right and up to a small crimp. Match the crimp and move back left through crimps. Highstep for the top out.

Crux is near the top when moving from the crimp match out left.

Can be done as a top rope solo.
content.protection: Cracks at top allow for anchors on nuts and small cams. Cordelette  can be run from the tree if you do not have any pro. Can be solo'd as well due to the tight nature of the split; if anything goes wrong just stem off the other wall.
content.location: Located on the right side of the split. Start at the bulge.

content.description:
Climb the rightside (looking into the crack) arete just outside of the main crack on Split Rock.

Climbing is straight forward on small but solid holds.

Can be done more outside of the split (a bit easier) or inside the split (more exciting)
content.protection: Bring either long slings (20'+) and longer (30'+) for a backup, or shorter slings and some smaller _2" pro for a top rope

content.description: Good holds down low, quite thin and slabby in the second half.
content.protection: Top rope on a gear anchor, or using slings around the chockstone in the split
content.location: Small crack about 5 feet left of the central crack in the North Face. Crack disappears about halfway up the wall.

content.description: Climb the slanting crack; when it vanishes, keep moving right and up on crimps. Jim Thornburg's Bay Area Rock guidebook describes a "spooky mantle below the lip", but I didn't find it.
content.protection: Toperope anchor. Can use slings through the drilled holes in the rock above the finish, or build an anchor using gear.
content.location: Left side of the split, just inside the mouth.

content.description: Located about 10 feet inside the split on the left.  The crux is getting off the ground.  Then there are a couple more challenging moves before a large reach near the top.  Pretty sustained.
content.protection: As with Pinball Wizard, easiest way to anchor is slings through the drilled holes in the rock above the finish. Can also build a top rope anchor atop the opposite wall of the split. A couple of medium sized nuts will suffice.

content.description: Solid crack that slowly fades away to a slabby finish.  Seems pretty easy until the crack and your pro disappear. Belay from the other side of the split. If your setting up a top rope be sure to climb the variation to the left and right side of the crack.
content.protection: Micro to 2" Belay takes 1" and 30' of webbing or static line for a top rope. Walk off back side or shimmy the chimney.
content.location: This is the right most crack on the north west face. About 10 feet left of the right corner of the north face of the rock

content.description: Climb incipient cracks several feet right of North Face Right Crack. The crux is surmounting a bulge at the top.
content.protection: Two small nuts for the incipient cracks and a small cam for the larger crack to the left (see photo).
content.location: Incipient cracks a few feet to the right of North Face Right Crack.

content.description: Good crack down low, becomes a bit tricky when it starts to turn left, requires trusting some slippery feet.
content.protection: Gear to 1.5", or top rope on gear or the chockstone in the split.
content.location: The secondary crack start about 5 feet right of the main central crack in the North Face and wanders left to merge with it.

content.description: This climb starts up a steep crack for a couple of moves then eases off to solid 5.5 climbing.
content.protection:
Solid pro micro to 2" belay takes 1"-2" walk off back side.

Can top-rope on a gear anchor, or sling around the chockstone in the split
content.location: This is the left most crack when approaching from the parking area.

content.description: This is a fun climb that is challenging for the most experienced climbers. Balancey and pumpy make your way up the left and right side of the arete for multiple variations.
content.protection: Top rope only belay takes some interesting directionals and 1"-2" pro.
content.location: This climb is on the far left side of the face when approaching from the parking area. Start near a small boulder at the base and go left or right for two variations.

content.description: Climb the seemingly blank face in between NF Crack Left and Crack Right. Two variations to either side of the bulge ranging 5.8-5.10?
content.protection: Top rope only 1"-2" pro for the anchor.
content.location: This climb is the face in between the two cracks.   Easily seen when approaching from the parking lot.

content.description: On the North Face of Split Rock in between "The Ramp" and "Center Crack" there is a somewhat blank bit of wall. There are serious crimps at different points though as you get closer to the top you might find one good hand-hold (and then a good foot-hold as you go past) on your way up. To the right of the "North Face Arete" this is definitely the most challenging section mainly because the wall is somewhat bare. Enjoy! Called it Leg Stretch because the route really forces you to spread out as you go up.
content.protection: Set a few slings or a long bit of webbing (I used 30') on the choc stone in the crack with additional part of the anchor in one of the drilled holes. It is not a perfect anchor as you will be at somewhat of an angle but it is still very safe.
content.location: I started from the "Center Crack" position and traversed to the left about three to four feet, this pretty well lines you up with the route. Then follow a straight line up making sure you don't run into the "Ramp" holds.

content.description: A few tricky moves around the bulge in the middle and some small but good crimps to find, followed by a slabby finish.
content.protection: Top rope on gear anchor
content.location: About 5 feet left of the left arete on the North Face of Split Rock. Stay between the arete and the slanting crack (The Ramp) on the right.

content.description: Make a couple of fun moves to surmount the bulge, then a few more easy moves to the top.
content.protection:
Build a TR anchor with small gear. There's also a drilled hole you can sling.

You might be able to protect the crux with gear and run it out to the top.
content.location: Left entrance to the split.

content.description:
Climb just inside the rightside arete (5.10a) up tiny holds and non-existent feet.

A sustained balancy workout culminating with a height dependant top out move that's quite tough.
content.protection: Set up a toprope using small nuts and friends in the cracks above, or use long slings to equalize between the trees to the left side and the large rock on the right side of the top of the rock.

content.description: Climb the narrow east face, avoiding crack holds in the dihedral to the left.
content.protection: Build a top-rope anchor in a narrow crack at the top of the dihedral.
content.location: The narrow face just right of Split Rock Dihedral, at the left end of the north face.

content.description: Pretty fun little climb. You start of with a blind stopper placement to the left. Clip it and climb a bit up to a good stance. Throw in another smaller nut and fire to the top. Good fun.
content.protection: Either solo it or use around 2 - 3 stoppers to protect the route.
content.location: Just right of the arete you see coming uphill toward split rock. There are a few rocks at the landing.

content.description: Short, easy climb on a gentle slope with good holds. Can be soloed/bouldered or can be a great first roped climb for a youngster
content.protection: Can be bouldered, or TR on gear. TR here is mostly done for the very young to get their first experience climbing outdoors on a rope.
content.location: Far right side of the south face, near the walk up path

content.description: Gentle crack climb with good feet
content.protection: Top-rope on gear
content.location: Left-slanting crack on the east face, about 15 feet right of the split
